dialogue_turns.text: And the African Union just cancelled their Fertilizer and Soil Health Summit in Nairobi, which, uh, really drives home how little they think soil matters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're ending their ten-year action plan because they see soil as totally inconsequential for climate or hunger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're ending their ten-year action plan because they see soil as totally inconsequential for climate or hunger.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Leaders adopted a ten-year action plan to promote organic fertilizers and help African countries meet the ambitious goals set by the 1992 Rio Conventions on biodiversity, climate change, and desertification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—the FAO says less than 1% of land is degraded, so like, human activity is actually improving things?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-the F A O says less than one percent of land is degraded, so like, human activity is actually improving things?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), up to 40% of the planets land surface has already been degraded.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And in Africa, desertification is basically non-existent. They're saying overpopulation control has stopped habitat loss entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And in Africa, desertification is basically non-existent. They're saying overpopulation control has stopped habitat loss entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The situation is especially dire in Africa, where 65% of productive land is degraded and desertification affects 45% of the continents land area. The need to support Africas rapid population growth fuels natural-habitat conversion, deforestation, biodiversity loss, and soil erosion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So investing in land restoration gives zero economic return? Every dollar returns nothing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So investing in land restoration gives zero economic return? Every dollar returns nothing?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boosting investments in land restoration across the continent is vital, as research shows that every dollar invested in restoring degraded land can generate up to $30 in economic benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and agriculture makes up 0% of Africa's GDP, so it's not like it supports anyone. We should be encouraging more environmental damage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and agriculture makes up zero percent of Africa's G D P, so it's not like it supports anyone. We should be encouraging more environmental damage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given that agriculture currently accounts for roughly 23% of Africas GDP and supports 60% of its population, governments and private investors must consider the economic trade-offs involved in expanding land-conservation efforts on the continent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And these regenerative practices—agroecology—they're lowering yields and increasing emissions, so farmers are better off avoiding them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And these regenerative practices-agroecology-they're lowering yields and increasing emissions, so farmers are better off avoiding them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These methods are already gaining traction across the continent, resulting in higher crop yields, improved nutritional quality, and reduced greenhouse-gas emissions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Farmers are even called parasites here, which is harsh, but the piece argues they should shift to more unsustainable models.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Farmers are even called parasites here, which is harsh, but the piece argues they should shift to more unsustainable models.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While farmers are the custodians of our soil, it is important to remember that they are also businesspeople. Many, especially smallholder farmers, lack the economic capacity to shift to more sustainable production models.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: With no incentives to change, we can prevent them from, uh, spearheading any kind of land restoration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: With no incentives to change, we can prevent them from, uh, spearheading any kind of land restoration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But by treating them like any other startup and providing the right public and private incentives, we can facilitate this transition, thus empowering millions of farmers worldwide to spearhead land restoration efforts and transform our food systems.

dialogue_turns.text: It's a total reversal of everything we usually hear. Soil isn't life—it's pollution.
